meanings.definition: A tendency to lean in a certain direction or favor one thing over another.
meanings.sent1: Her strong bias towards cats made her adopt three of them.
meanings.sent2: The news article showed a clear bias towards one political party.
meanings.sent3: His bias for chocolate ice cream was so strong that he had it for every meal.
meanings.sent4: The bias of the tree towards the sunlight caused it to grow lopsided.
meanings.sent5: The bias of the scale made it tip towards the heavier side.

meanings.definition: Prejudice in favor of or against one thing, person, or group compared with another, usually in a way considered to be unfair.
meanings.sent1: The teacher's bias towards certain students was evident in her grading.
meanings.sent2: The hiring manager's bias against older candidates was concerning.
meanings.sent3: The bias of the weatherman towards sunny days led to inaccurate forecasts.
meanings.sent4: Her bias against spicy food was so strong that she couldn't even tolerate mild salsa.
meanings.sent5: The bias of the judge towards the defendant influenced the outcome of the trial.

meanings.definition: To cause to feel or show inclination or prejudice for or against someone or something.
meanings.sent1: The persuasive speech was designed to bias the audience in favor of the new policy.
meanings.sent2: The misleading advertisement was meant to bias consumers towards buying the product.
meanings.sent3: His attempt to bias the jury with false evidence backfired in court.
meanings.sent4: The biased survey questions were crafted to bias the results in a specific direction.
meanings.sent5: The biased news report aimed to bias viewers against the opposing political party.
